results.title: Thanks for the Memories
results.creator_credit: Richard Greenhalgh, Csilla Csongvay and ACMI
results.brief_description: The people of Nanneella understand the value of bringing the community together as a way of raising morale and showing support in times of hardship. The town organised a community event in honour of the ACMI in the Regions visit to film in the area. The theme was water and the event was called ‘Thanks for the Memories’. Over 100 people attended the event which featured; music, poetry, raffles, mystery objects, food and lots of laughter.

results.title: Nanneella Primary School
results.creator_credit: Jason White, Csilla Csongvay and ACMI
results.brief_description: This small rural Primary School of 26 students is at the heart of Nanneella and its residents. With a motto of ‘A School and Community Together’ the Primary School is an integral part of all town events and social gatherings. The students are engaging and fun young individuals with clear ideas and hopes for the future. This film also features a performance from ‘Power Wars’, a musical piece that incorporates science and drama and won Nanneella Primary School the 2009 Archimedes Award.

results.title: My Colbo
results.brief_description: This film takes us on a tour of Colbinabbin and surrounds from the point of view of a number of locals. From the Old Cellar and Community Well to Chinaman’s Bend and Marian’s old family home that is covered in writings from the past, this story is full of historical facts and current realities. It also includes the story of the short-lived but successful Colbinabbin Tractor Pull and the once vibrant Lake Cooper which is now dry and has been for some years.

results.title: The McGillivray Family
results.creator_credit: Jonathon Hutchinson, Csilla Csongvay and ACMI
results.brief_description: The story of the McGillivrays takes place in Gunbower on Saturday morning at the Gunbower Football Complex. This is a portrait of a family that has always worked the land, either as farmers or sheep shearers. They share their love of sports and concerns about the effects of the drought on small regional towns. All with a sense of humour and a never give up attitude that families need to survive in the current climate.

results.title: The Reserve
results.creator_credit: Jonathon Hutchinson, Csilla Csongvay and ACMI
results.brief_description: This film shows what a group of passionate individuals can achieve to create a place for the whole town to enjoy. Volunteers and paid workers dedicated their time and energy to cleaning up Crown land in the middle of Nanneella. With assistance from the whole town and surrounding area the Nanneella Bushland Reserve is now used by the community for bonfires, social gatherings or just to sit and enjoy a picnic.

results.title: Gunbower: Family Albums
results.creator_credit: David Meagher, Csilla Csongvay and ACMI
results.brief_description: This film features life long residents of Gunbower and their family connections to three historically rich properties. From Greg Toll’s ancestral home in Kow Swamp to the Old Butter Factory in the heart of the town to Masters Landing on the shores of the Murray River. Each location resonates with childhood memories of times past.

results.title: Colbo Nights
results.creator_credit: Dean Lawry, Kim Montgomery and ACMI
results.brief_description: Football practice, barbequed snags and a couple of beers at the pub. This is Thursday night in Colbinabbin and you can meet local characters such as Slab, Meathead and Stewballs. The atmosphere is one of a close knit community that loves sports, live music and supports each other through good times and bad.

results.title: Mary and Max: The Exhibition: interview with Adam Elliot March 2010

video_links.name: Mary and Max: The Exhibition: interview with Adam Elliot March 2010

results.brief_description: Oscar winning animation director and writer Adam Elliot speaks candidly about his stop frame animation processes and, more importantly, about why he makes films. Adam also talks about the challenges he faced during the making of his first feature film ‘Mary and Max’.
results.title_for_label: Mary and Max: The Exhibition: interview with Adam Elliot March 2010
results.description: Oscar winning animation director and writer Adam Elliot speaks candidly about his stop frame animation processes and, more importantly, about why he makes films. Adam also talks about the challenges he faced during the making of his first feature film ‘Mary and Max’.

results.title: Harvie Krumpet
results.creator_credit: Adam Elliot, Melanie Coombs, Australian Film Commission, Film Victoria, Melodrama Pictures and SBS Independent
results.brief_description:
Adam Elliot’s bittersweet claymation short work opens in Poland in 1922 with the birth of Harvek Milos Krumpetzki - an innocent child beguiled with the world, born to doting and quite dotty parents.

Despite being mercilessly teased as a child, Harvek maintains interest in his surrounds, encouraged by his mother who assists him in collecting wonderful ‘fakts’ about the world. One night Harvek’s life is irrevocably altered when WWII breaks out and he migrates to a faraway land - Australia. In an attempt to assimilate Harvek changes his name to Harvie Krumpet and, in the suburb of Spotswood, begins a new life involving marriage, parenthood and finally, old age.

Winner of the 2003 Academy Award for Best Animated Short Film, and narrated by Geoffrey Rush.

results.title: Blue Murder: Part 2
results.creator_credit: Michael Jenkins, Rod Allan, Australian Broadcasting Corporation, Film Finance Corporation Australia and Southern Star Entertainment
results.brief_description:
Based on the events that led to the Royal Commission on Police Corruption in New South Wales, ‘Blue Murder’ is a riveting and exceptionally well executed thriller about police corruption and gangland criminal activity in 1980s Australia.
Richard Roxburgh is outstanding as Roger Rogerson, the larrikin police chief who built a lucrative ‘alternative’ career based on bribery, drug money and murder. Tony Martin is Neddy Smith, one of Australia’s most notorious underworld thugs.
Rogerson and Smith’s activities are threatened when a young police officer, Michael Drury (Steve Bastoni), declines a bribe offered to him by Rogerson. From that moment on, ‘Blue Murder’ depicts how Drury’s involvement in acting as an informer on Rogerson’s activities led to increasingly desperate and murderous acts by both police and crims.
Acclaimed internationally as a landmark television mini-series, ‘Blue Murder’ was for years unable to be screened in NSW or available for view on video in Australia due to elements of the story being seen as prejudicial to legal trials in NSW and Federal Courts.
Cast also inlcudes Alex Dimitriades, Peter Phelps and John Hargreaves.
First broadcast (outside NSW) September 21st, 1995.
